title: How to Make a Commonplace Book

steps.headline: Gather essentials.
steps.description: Before starting a book get a notebook, preferably one made of recycled paper, a pen and a nice cup of tea or coffee. Find a comfortable place to sit.

steps.headline: Consider why you are reading.
steps.description: This is a tip in general for whenever you read- always know why you are reading a book. What do you wish to achieve by reading the book? Is it for a research essay? Or for a presentation? Or is it just so you learn something new?

steps.headline: Read.
steps.description: This is the easiest step of all. Just open the book and start reading.

steps.headline: Analyze the information you read.
steps.description: Ask yourself questions like "What does this information mean? ", "Do I have to look up something else to understand this information better?" etc.

steps.headline: Refer to other books or the Internet for background information to put the book into historical context.
steps.description: This works for both fiction and non-fiction.

steps.headline: Write down quotes that strike you, key words for quick reference and your thoughts about what you are reading.
steps.description: [The image above could give you an idea as to how to organise the information on a page]. You could also write down any words that you are unfamiliar with. Write down the meaning and the sentence you read it in on a separate page which could be maintained as the glossary for your commonplace book. This could help with building your vocabulary.

steps.headline: Go through the notes every now and then and add to it.
steps.description: Use post-its for keywords or write the information on another sheet and clip it in the right section.
